dublinCore.dc:title: 117 HR 6755 IH: Cooperation Among Police, Tech, and Users to Resist Exploitation Act
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Bilirakis introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce, and in addition to the Committee on the Judiciary, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To require the Comptroller General of the United States to submit to Congress a report on big tech and law enforcement, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Cooperation Among Police, Tech, and Users to Resist Exploitation Act or the CAPTURE Act.

section.header: GAO study and report on big tech and law enforcement

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General of the United States shall complete a study on the following:

paragraph.text: How social media companies currently communicate, consult, and coordinate with Federal, State, and local law enforcement to address illegal content and activity online.
Document successes and failures by social media companies in cooperating with Federal, State, and local law enforcement agencies in events of imminent injury or death to individuals.
Ways in which social media companies can better communicate, consult, and coordinate with Federal, State, and local law enforcement to address illegal content and activity online.

subsection.text: Not later than 6 months after the completion of the study required under subsection (a), the Comptroller General of the United States shall submit to the Committee on Energy and Commerce of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate a report that contains—

paragraph.text: the results of the study conducted pursuant to subsection (a); and

subparagraph.text: develop legislation that may assist social media companies to better communicate, consult, and coordinate with Federal, State, and local law enforcement to address illegal content and activity online; and
require social media companies to establish a single point of contact in every State for Federal, State, and local law enforcement entities.
